questions.question: Which action below is an example of a physical change?

answers.content: Melting an ice block so it becomes water
answers.explanation: The ice changes state from solid to liquid but is still water.
Baking causes a chemical change that cannot be reversed easily.
Burning changes the chemicals in the match head.
Rusting forms a new substance (iron oxide).

questions.question: Explain why inflating a balloon is considered a physical change.

answers.content: The balloon is still made of rubber; only its shape and size change when air is added or released.

questions.question: Which of the following objects from the classroom materials list is made of metal?

answers.explanation: Aluminium is a metal.
A craft stick is made of wood.
A plastic bottle is made from plastic.
Cotton fabric is made from plant fibres.

questions.question: List two different actions you could use to physically change a sheet of paper.

answers.content: Possible answers include: folding, cutting, tearing, rolling, crushing, or bending the paper.

questions.question: When a scientist watches a rubber band being stretched, which sense are they mainly using to make observations?

answers.explanation: They look at the rubber band to see how it changes.

questions.question: Draw two pictures of a rubber band: one before it is stretched and one after it has been stretched. Label your drawings to show the change in shape.

answers.content: Student provides two clearly labelled drawings showing a normal and a stretched rubber band, demonstrating understanding that only shape/size changes.

questions.question: Which statement best describes a physical change?

answers.content: The material keeps the same properties but its form or size changes.
answers.explanation: Physical changes do not alter the material’s chemical composition.

answers.content: New materials with different properties are always formed.
answers.explanation: That describes a chemical change.
Many physical changes can be reversed.
Physical changes can occur without heat.

questions.question: Which picture best shows the action of BENDING a material?

answers.content: A child pulling a rubber band to make it longer.
answers.explanation: This is stretching, not bending.

answers.content: A student curving a plastic straw into a letter U.
answers.explanation: Bending means curving the material without breaking it.

answers.content: Two hands twisting the lid off a jar.
answers.explanation: This is twisting.

answers.content: A ball of clay being rolled into a long snake.
answers.explanation: This is rolling, not bending.

questions.question: Which of the following materials is MOST likely to stretch without breaking?

answers.explanation: Wood is rigid and snaps instead of stretching.
Rubber is elastic and can stretch easily.
Dry spaghetti is brittle and breaks rather than stretches.
Ceramic is hard and rigid.

questions.question: A physical change such as twisting a pipe cleaner is usually:

answers.explanation: Many physical changes can be reversed.

answers.content: A change in the material's chemical make-up.
answers.explanation: Chemical composition stays the same in a physical change.

answers.content: Reversible and keeps the same material.
answers.explanation: Physical changes alter shape, not substance.

answers.content: Possible only when heat is added.
answers.explanation: Heat is not always needed for physical changes like twisting.

questions.question: Name TWO different actions (other than bend, stretch or twist) that can physically change the shape of a material.

answers.content: Possible correct answers include: roll, push, pull, squash, squeeze, fold.

questions.question: During the investigation, which tool helped the class organise and compare their observations?

answers.content: A table with tick or cross boxes
answers.explanation: Tables allow clear organisation of results.

questions.question: For a material to be bent, stretched or twisted it must be:

answers.explanation: Flexibility/elasticity allows shape change without breaking.

questions.question: Why is candy in the Rainbow Candy Making video WARMED before it is twisted and stretched?

answers.content: Heating makes the candy softer and more flexible so it can be twisted and stretched without breaking.

questions.question: Draw a pipe cleaner before and after you bend it into the shape of the letter S. Label the drawing with the word "bent".

answers.content: Full marks: two clear drawings (before & after), shape resembles S, label "bent" present.

questions.question: What happens to frozen fruit when it is warmed?

answers.content: It thaws and becomes softer and juicier.
answers.explanation: Adding heat melts the ice inside the fruit, so it softens.
Freezing harder would require removing heat, not adding it.
Fruit contains water that first thaws to liquid before any evaporation might occur.

questions.question: When heat is added to a solid chocolate bar, which change is most likely?

answers.explanation: Heating raises the temperature above chocolate’s melting point.

questions.question: Name one of the five senses you used while investigating the frozen fruit.

answers.content: Any one of: sight, smell, taste, touch, hearing

questions.question: Cooling a material removes energy from its particles. This causes the particles to:

answers.explanation: Less thermal energy means less particle movement.

questions.question: What is the name of the process that turns liquid water into ice?
Draw and label what a piece of cheese looks like before it is heated and after it is melted.

answers.content: Teacher-marked drawing showing solid cheese (before) and melted cheese (after).

questions.question: State one safe procedure you should follow when handling food during a science investigation.

answers.content: Example correct responses: wash hands before touching food; use clean utensils; keep food on a clean surface.

questions.question: Which action would help a person warm up on a cold day?

answers.content: Putting on a thick, woollen jumper.
answers.explanation: The jumper traps body heat.

answers.content: Standing in front of an open freezer.
Holding an ice cube in each hand.
